journal-title-group.journal-title: The Journal of Financial and Quantitative Analysis

publisher.publisher-name: University of Washington School of Business Administration, University of Utah David Eccles School of Business, and New York University Leonard N. Stern School of Business

title-group.article-title: The Poor Predictive Performance of Asset Pricing Models

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 2008 Michael G. Foster School of Business

abstract.p: This paper examines time-series forecast errors of expected returns from conditional and unconditional asset pricing models for portfolio and individual firm equity returns. A new result that increases predictive precision concerning model specification and forecasting is introduced. Conditional versions of the models generally produce higher mean squared errors than unconditional versions for step ahead prediction. This holds for individual firm data when the instruments are firm specific. Mean square forecast error decompositions indicate that the asset pricing models produce relatively unbiased predictions, but the variance is severe enough to ruin the step ahead predictive ability beyond that of a constant benchmark.
